body.p:
Your esteemed
fvr of the 19th Ins came safe to hand
with a note to my sister, who begs me to
say in reply, that she recollects during Mr
W. Life, of his having received the Daily
Prayer as well as the other prayers, that
he paid for the D Pryer & when the others
were presented he declined taking them
because he did subscribe but for the single
volume, my sister having a complete
as well as himself.

I am as anxious as possible that
your subscribers should pay them ar
-rears regularly every year, for when
they get two or 3 years in arrears it
is difficult to collect, I will do all
I can to urge them, those in the
country I have to write to, as they
seldom are in town. Dr. Raphael
has been ? since his
arrival, he took a Room at the Pavillion
I enclose the Proceeding of your congre

gation in relation to him, & have
addressed you as a correspondent
not desirous of appearing in Person
so I have given you the outline make
any additions & corrections or prefaces
you think necessary, as too much
cannot be said of him, he is an
able ? for you & I hope you
will act together, for as I told him
you were the only Israelite in
America, who had done work
for the cause of Israel, time
& money have been of no consi
=deration to you for the cause & ele
vation of true Judaism, He
is a great man, eloquent & pro
found & Logical—He has been
very unfortunate like yourself in
differing from the great Poz
=nanski—on the same day that our
? called & as I had just finished
my address, Mr. P & the commiller ?
Hojel? popped in & Mr P as ? addressed
him & in conclusion hoped his views
& reforms coincided with the Doctor

& the Doctor replied to him in not
the most affectionate manner, for he
could not sanction or argue with any
man or any change that would prove
Sch? in Israel, however unimpor
tant the change, & then Mr P. undertook
in the presence of all the visitors & step
-ping from the object of his visit,
went more fully in to the reforms innovations of his
congregation & himself—the conversation
lasted about 2 Hours as Mr P. had to
leave on business but desired to continue
the Discussion, when Mr Rosenfeldt sug
=gested that the discussion or friendly con
versation be ? before Both
congregations at Hebrew Orphan Hall on
the Sunday following which was agreed
to by the Dr. I was much opposed to it the
more I reflected upon it & it was not un
-til the Thursday follg that I gave my consent
because I know his followers would not
admit their errors & it was a ? of
time & words.—The meeting took place
& I need not tell you the result, Mr
P was as a child in the hands of a giant

Before the Doctor would go into an
examination of the introduction of an
organ or the discontinuance of the
use of the 2d day of Festivals, of which
Mr. P had brought a cartload of Books,
the Doctor took him & his followers “all
a back” (as the suitors say) & struck
at the root of innovation, & the
main stay of Judaism. The Creed
—the addition & the total abolition
of a portion The non fullfilment
of the prophecy of the messiah—& the resurrection
of the Dead, which last article
you are aware of is not upon
their tablet in the synagogue

To give you an account of the
conversation would occupy too
much time & paper, but the con
clusion & ? of Dr R, of nu
Pos is that he is either a fool or
knave, for he has hitherto palmed
on us, as Albo' opinion & he thought
he could do it upon the Dr. the
opinions of others, which Albo refutes
most powerfully & which agrees with me
great sagery & the great Marmonides

It so happened that the Doctor in his
excitement could not refer to the part
but he had translated it & is in the ?
Rev? & promised his audience to have
it reprinted at his own expense to
verify his assertion, he has done so

But such a mokkas as P & his
followers obtained was as merited
as it was severe. He told them
they were ? Jews. For ?
are jews but those who believe in
the written & oral Laws. The coming
of the Messiah & the resurrection of
the dead.—They all felt the rebuke
& they all say he is of course a
Bigot like you, I suppose you'll
say you like to be in such com
-pany if
Dr. R is a bigot. The most
conspicuous of those who have felt
the truth of Dr R castigation is
Dr Philip Cohen, to whom the Dr
had brought a letter from A Hart
& to whom Mr Josh Lazarus had sent
to me tickets for his lectures to dis
pose of & to show how small a mat
ter it was he returned them in a
note saying “that the illiberal cause
of Dr R will prevent him from dis
posing of the tickets, so you see
that the Dr might have made

20 or 40 Dolls. but it so happens
that one Lecture had already taken
place & yet Mr Cohen had not
distributed or used even a single
ticket—His Lectures therefore has
been attended by a most respec
table audience, but not so nume
-rous as I could have worked through
? proportionate to our
population I am pleased to say that
all the Israelites in our city with one or two
exceptions have attended his lectures
& have been most agreeable enter
tained & enlightened, he again Lectures
tomorrow at our Shool XXXVI Ezekiel
? XXIV—& on Sunday he addresses our
children & teachers of the school.

I must stop Mr Levin is pre
paring an account of the
conversation & intends sending it to
you. I have also sent a copy
of the proceedings as enclosed to the
Asmoneon—if not too late for the
March Occident will you mend
it? I ? you are well

in which I am yours by all
? I remain?

The Doctor will leave for Savan
-nah on Thursday next, where
he will lecture on Saturday night
& thence retrace his steps to MS
not having time ? him to
visit New Orleans & return to NC
by the Passover.

I should have been highly gra
tified to have had you here this
week most especially, but hope
you will soon ? in upon us

I forgot to say that Dr Wise arrived
here last week & delivered his 1st Lec
-ture on Saturday afternoon, but it did me
great pleasure ? when members
had heard the great Raphael in the
morning, on Sunday he helped his Proty
-type, & on Monday eve (Purim) he told his
congregation that they would not & could not
as American Jews think of going back

to Jerusalem to be under the
messiah a King when
